entry.title: Configuring OAuth 2.0 Authentication between SAP API Management and SAP Cloud Integration
entry.content:
Alright, let‚Äôs get started, buddy! üòÉ

Assuming API Management is active in your Integration Suite tenant, the first step is to set up the API Proxy.

Step 1: Create an API Proxy to Generate an Access Token 

 

Create an API Proxy using the URL type, and provide any dummy hostname since the target endpoint won‚Äôt actually be invoked.

 

After creating the API Proxy, set the Target Endpoint to ‚ÄúNone‚Äù in the Proxy Endpoint section, as shown in the screenshot below, and click on save.


Step 2 : Add a policy to generate the OAuth 2.0 Authentication.

In the Proxy Endpoint‚Äôs PreFlow, add the OAuth policy, ensuring it is applied on the incoming request stream.

OAuth 2.0 ‚Äì Used to generate the access token for the API call.

<OAuthV2 async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
	<ExternalAuthorization>false</ExternalAuthorization>
	<GrantType>request.queryparam.grant_type</GrantType>
	<Operation>GenerateAccessToken</Operation>
	<GenerateResponse enabled="true"/>
	<SupportedGrantTypes>
		<GrantType>client_credentials</GrantType>
	</SupportedGrantTypes>
</OAuthV2>

Step 3: Create a Product in the Engage section of Integration Suite

Add the API Proxy GenerateAccessToken to the Product APIM_Product

Step 4 : Create a subscription in the Developer Hub

Navigate to Developer Hub ‚Üí My Workspace ‚Üí Create New Subscription (e.g., APIM_Product).



You will get these two items from APIM_Product: The Application Key (your username) and the Application Secret (your password).

Step 5 : Now, let‚Äôs test the API Proxy for GenerateAccessToken

Test the API Proxy using Basic Authentication by supplying the Application Key as the username, the Application Secret as the password, and adding the grant_type as a query parameter. I‚Äôve also attached a screenshot showing the generated access token.

Step 6 : Create API Provider

To validate the setup, you must create an API Provider. Navigate to API Provider, click Create, and enter the following details:

  1. Type: Cloud Integration
  2. Host
  3. Port
  4. Client ID
  5. Client Secret
  6. Token URL*

Click Test Connection; you should receive an ‚ÄúOK‚Äù message with a 200 response code. I‚Äôve attached a screenshot for your reference.

Step 7 : Develop the Integration Flow to serve as the proxy and then deploy it.

I have created a simple Integration Flow that includes a Content Modifier with the body .I‚Äôve attached a screenshot for your reference.

Step 8 : create a proxy using API Provider

Select the provider, click Discover, choose the API, and then click Create


Your proxy will be created and then assign the API Proxy to the Product as shown in below screenshot.

Step 9: Now, let‚Äôs verify the access token
Apply the OAuthV2 policy to the Demo API Proxy.

OAuth 2.0 - To verify the OAuth Token generated.

<OAuthV2 async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
   <ExternalAuthorization>false</ExternalAuthorization>
   <Operation>VerifyAccessToken</Operation>
   <GenerateResponse enabled="true"/>
</OAuthV2>

Assign Message ‚Äì If you encounter the error {"fault":{"faultstring":"Unsupported Encoding \"br\"","detail":{"errorcode":"protocol.http.UnsupportedEncoding"}}}, it's because BR (Brotli) is a compression format typically used by backends for webpage loading, and it is not supported here. Using the Assign Message policy helps remove this unsupported encoding so the message can reach the target successfully


Assign Message 

<AssignMessage async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<Remove>
		<Headers>
			<Header name="Authorization"/>
		</Headers>
	</Remove>
	<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>false</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
	<AssignTo createNew="false" type="request">request</AssignTo>
</AssignMessage>

Click on save and deploy .

Step 9 : Testing Time
In Postman, select OAuth 2.0 as the authentication type, then:

  • Set the Access Token URL
  • Enter the Client ID
  • Enter the Client Secret
  • grant_type=client_credentials
  • Click Get New Access Token


From Cloud Integration

From API Management 

And we‚Äôre done! OAuth 2.0 Authentication is configured for SAP API Management in SAP Cloud Integration. You may now take a victory sip of coffee‚Äîyou earned it üòé

Reference

https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/oauth-v2-0 

https://docs.apigee.com/api-platform/security/oauth/oauth-20-client-credentials-grant-type

entry.title: Issue in S/4HANA ‚Üí SAP Sales Cloud v2 Integration: Wrong Sender/Receiver System IDs Passed
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

we are currently implementing the standard integration between SAP S/4HANA On-Premise and SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 using the official SAP Integration Suite package:

‚ÄúSAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration for Sales Processes with SAP S/4HANA‚Äù
(in particular the iFlow ‚ÄúReplicate Sales Order and Sales Quote from SAP S/4HANA‚Äù)

During our setup we noticed a behavior that appears to be incorrect or at least not documented. The iFLow in SAP Standard expects an IDOC Structure (here message type COD_REPLICATE_SALES_ORDER)

What we observed

When S/4HANA sends sales order replication data to SAP Integration Suite, it uses the following system identifiers:

  • Sender system: S4HCLNT100

  • Receiver system: MY1001354

These are the classical Logical System names.

However, SAP Sales Cloud v2 expects the system identifiers that are defined in the Communication System setup inside Sales Cloud v2, for example:

  • Sender system: S4H_100

  • Receiver system: sap_cloud_crm_my1001354

Because of this mismatch, the standard iFlow fails unless we manually change the mapping inside the iFlow.
After adjusting the mapping, the messages are processed correctly.

Why this is confusing

In the Sales Cloud v2 integration:

  • There is no place in S/4HANA where these system IDs can be adapted specifically for Sales Cloud v2.

  • The standard content in SAP Integration Suite does not expose parameters to override sender/receiver IDs.

  • The documentation does not mention any required mapping.

This means:
The standard iFlow expects the Sales Cloud v2 Communication System IDs, but S/4HANA always sends Logical System IDs.

So the iFlow and the S/4HANA standard do not match each other out-of-the-box.

üí¨ Our question to the community

Is this behavior expected?
Or is this a gap/bug in the standard integration?

Also:
Is there any hidden configuration in S/4HANA to control which system identifiers are passed to the iFlow?
We could not find any.

At the moment, we had to modify the iFlow (which we would prefer to avoid), and we‚Äôd like to know:

  • Does SAP plan to adjust the integration content?

  • Or have other customers found a clean configuration-based solution?

Any guidance, insights, or experiences would be highly appreciated. üòä

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: CPI HTTP Receiver always returns 400 ‚ÄúSyntax Error‚Äù although same JSON works in Postman
entry.content:
Hi Everyone,

We are trying to call a BZSt REST endpoint from SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) using the HTTP Receiver adapter. The goal is to send a small JSON request from our SAP backend to the German EVATR service and receive a validation response.

The same request (same URL, same JSON body, same token/parameters) works perfectly in Postman. In CPI, however, we consistently receive an HTTP 400 error from the target system.

The error message in the CPI log is:

org.apache.camel.component.ahc.AhcOperationFailedException:
HTTP operation failed invoking https://api.evatr.vies.bzst.de/app/v1/abfrage with statusCode: 400

 The response body from the server is an HTML error page:

<html>
<head>
<base href="/error_path/">
<title>400 Bad Request</title>
</head>
<body>
<h1>Bad Request</h1>
<p>The server detected a syntax error in your request.<br>
Check your request and all parameters.</p>

<p>Your request ID was: aSW1_biQek9iXbaem_MTxwAABZY</p>
</body>
</html>

In the meantime, we have tested quite a lot of variations. We tried many different header combinations, including explicitly setting headers like Content-Type, Accept, Host, and Content-Length, and we experimented with the ‚ÄúAllowed / Request Headers‚Äù setting of the HTTP Receiver adapter (including using *). None of these attempts changed the behavior ‚Äì CPI still only seems to forward a very small set of headers, and additional headers set via a Content Modifier often do not appear in the actual outbound call (according to the HTTP_Receiver_Adapter_Request_Headers attachment).

We also experimented with the payload itself: different JSON formats, slightly modified test payloads, sending the exact same body as Postman, and even building a minimal iFlow where the JSON body is hard-coded in a Content Modifier and sent directly to the HTTP receiver. The result is always the same 400 response from the BZSt service, so it does not appear to be a simple syntax issue in the JSON itself.

What could be the reason for this behavior, and does anyone know how to resolve it or what else we should check?

entry.title: Infrastructure as Code on APIM through the SDK
entry.content:
We are building an API portal on SAP Integration Suite exposing api's from SAP Commerce Cloud for a large global client.

To do this we need to configure provider, proxies, policies, certificates, endpoints, api products etc. on SAP APIM.

We are using 4 BTP instances/environments for this: CI, Dev, QA and Prod.

Since we don't want to manually set up all these resources on each environment, we are building a custom IaC setup, which can configure all these resources automatically from GitHub actions.

Our IaC setup uses the SDK's provided for BTP and APIM to configures the instances. Not an easy task, since the SDK's are very poorly documented by SAP.

Part of the setup is to have GitHub actions run on pull requests to configure an entire resource setup needed for running automated api tests against the API products defined on APIM.

All of the above seems like standard features which SAP should provide for BTP and APIM through something like a terraform provider.

Is anybody else working on something like this?
